propositions.text: Introduction of the story and its context.
The story is titled 'Yellow River Ghost Coffin 2 - Corpse Transformation Nine Dragon Pit'.
It is related to 'Nen Pai San Shu'.
Information about where to find reviews, updates, and related book recommendations is provided.
The provided URL is http://www.xiaoshuotxt.com/xuanyi/6182/.
TXT Novel Paradise (http://www.xiaoshuotxt.com) is described as a literary website.
The website offers classic literary works, martial arts novels, romance novels, and humanities/social science books for online reading.
TXT e-books are available for free mobile download and reading.
Chapter 1: Battle with Ghost Corpses.
The narrator, Shao Ye, and Ya Tou are in a tomb.
Light from a flashlight reflects off a jade platform.
An empty armor lies on the jade platform.
Shao Ye cautiously touches the armor's head.
The narrator hears a 'shashasha' sound, like footsteps.
The narrator experiences a growing sense of terror.
The narrator shouts 'Don't!' when Shao Ye tries to pull something from the armor.
A sound of iron chains hitting each other is heard.
Ya Tou jumps onto the narrator's back, startled.
Shao Ye exclaims, 'What is this thing?'
A door has opened in the southeast corner of the tomb.
Four shadowy figures with iron chains are approaching.
Ya Tou asks fearfully what these figures are.
The narrator curses and admits he doesn't know what they are.
The black corpses resemble those seen in the stone wall cracks.
These black corpses are difficult to deal with.
Shao Ye shoots one of the black corpses with a crossbow.
The arrow pierces the corpse's head, but it shows no reaction.
Shao Ye panics as the crossbow proves ineffective.
The narrator rallies Shao Ye and Ya Tou, urging them to fight.
Shao Ye, angered by the narrator's words, charges at a black corpse with a bamboo arrow.
The narrator follows Shao Ye, grabbing a bamboo arrow.
Upon close inspection, the black corpse's appearance is described: dark, with rotten features, but open, blood-red eyes.
The corpse's legs are chained, but its back is not.
The black corpse smiles at the narrator.
The narrator feels fear but realizes there is nowhere to run.
A foul smell of decaying corpses fills the air.
Shao Ye calls out for help as he is attacked.
The narrator stabs a black corpse with a bamboo arrow, but it is grabbed.
The narrator narrowly escapes being bitten by a black corpse.
Shao Ye is entangled by two black corpses.
The narrator rescues Shao Ye, feeling pain in his shoulder.
Shao Ye, shaken, asks if he is alive.
Shao Ye sits down, seemingly giving up.
Ya Tou screams as a black corpse pursues her around the coffin bed.
Shao Ye jumps up to rescue Ya Tou.
Three black corpses attack the narrator.
The narrator wonders how the corpses are controlled and can see.
Shao Ye rescues Ya Tou, but Ya Tou runs towards the narrator.
The narrator warns Ya Tou to stay away.
Ya Tou says she has a stomach ache and needs to relieve herself.
Ya Tou goes behind the coffin bed to relieve herself.
One of the black corpses moves to attack Ya Tou.
The narrator attacks a corpse with his flashlight, shouting defiantly.
Shao Ye tries to block the corpse pursuing Ya Tou but is caught by another.
Ya Tou screams, and a heavy object falls.
The narrator rushes to Shao Ye's aid.
The narrator and Shao Ye fall to the ground.
Shao Ye coughs, with visible marks on his neck.
Three black corpses attack the narrator and Shao Ye.
The narrator believes they are doomed.
The narrator opens his eyes to see Ya Tou standing, and the black corpses on the ground, decaying into black water.
Shao Ye asks what happened.
The narrator notices Ya Tou holding something.
Ya Tou starts crying.
Shao Ye asks what's wrong.
The narrator identifies the object in Ya Tou's hand as a used feminine hygiene pad with bloodstains.
The narrator questions if this item defeated the black corpses.
Shao Ye asks why Ya Tou has the hygiene pad.
Ya Tou cries harder.
The narrator tells Ya Tou to stop crying, dismissing the hygiene pad.
Shao Ye questions if the corpses feared the hygiene pad.
The narrator explains Ya Tou's stomach ache and her needing to relieve herself.
Ya Tou was disturbed by a black corpse while relieving herself.
In anger and fear, Ya Tou threw the used hygiene pad at the corpse.
The black corpse was defeated by the hygiene pad.
Ya Tou, realizing the item's effect, rushed to help the narrator and Shao Ye.
The black corpses fell when touched by the hygiene pad.
Shao Ye is surprised by the event.
The narrator recalls hearing that such creatures fear filth and impurity.
The narrator speculates about the efficacy of a virgin's menstrual blood.
The black corpses have rotted into black water.
The iron chains remain, appearing blacker.
Ya Tou points out the chains.
Shao Ye touches a black chain with a bamboo arrow, and the arrow rapidly decays.
Shao Ye exclaims about the potent corpse poison.
The narrator worries about Shao Ye's earlier encounter with the corpses.
Shao Ye insists he is fine.
The narrator observes the marks on Shao Ye's neck.
The narrator plans to study the jade coffin bed.
A 'shashasha' sound is heard again.
The narrator and Ya Tou exchange a look.
Shao Ye asks what the sound is.
Ya Tou whispers that it sounds like footsteps.
The presence of footsteps in the tomb is considered impossible, as dead people don't walk.
The narrator, Ya Tou, and Shao Ye turn towards the sound's origin.
Despite fear, their survival instinct makes them bolder.
The sound seems to be coming from the entrance they used.
The narrator suggests they hide and observe.
Ya Tou points to the beams above.
Shao Ye climbs up the rope first.
Ya Tou climbs up, the footsteps getting closer.
The narrator quickly climbs up.
They hide on the beams, but see nothing.
The narrator recalls the concept of 'echo walls' in ancient architecture.
Echo walls can create sounds to disturb people.
The narrator speculates that these walls might be intentionally built to trap visitors.
The narrator remembers the small door that appeared.
The narrator observes the small door, describing it as more like a 'dog hole'.
The narrator sees a black shadow near the dog hole, resembling a person.
Ya Tou nudges the narrator, who almost falls.
Ya Tou and Shao Ye stare at the entrance, their faces pale.
A figure emerges from the entrance.
The narrator feels they have encountered someone unexpectedly.
The narrator believes it is a living person.
The narrator holds Ya Tou's cold, sweaty hand.
The figure walks towards the coffin river without any light source.
Ya Tou recognizes the person as 'Old Bian'.
Shao Ye nudges Ya Tou, who signals to the narrator.
Shao Ye shines his flashlight on Old Bian.
The narrator considers two explanations for Old Bian's presence: he faked his death to tomb rob, or his body was moved there.
Old Bian reacts to the light and looks up towards their hiding spot.
Shao Ye shouts and falls into the coffin river.
Old Bian's face is pale and shows signs of decay.
The narrator throws a rope to Shao Ye, but it's unsuccessful.
Shao Ye falls into the coffin river.
The narrator and Ya Tou slide down the rope.
The coffin river is filled with tentacles.
The tentacles cannot leave the river.
They manage to pull Shao Ye out.
Shao Ye states that there is something strange beneath the coffin river.
The narrator searches for Old Bian but finds no trace of him.
The narrator is shocked to find that Old Bian and the Professor have disappeared.
The narrator questions how the dead can reappear as living beings.
Shao Ye asks where Old Bian went.
Ya Tou asks if they have seen the Professor.
The narrator recalls the Professor's body being in the coffin river earlier.
The Professor's body is also missing.
The narrator suspects the shadow near the dog hole was the Professor.
The narrator, Shao Ye, and Ya Tou walk towards the small hole.
The narrator asks Shao Ye if he is truly alright.
The narrator questions why the black corpses and tentacles did not affect Shao Ye.
Shao Ye asks for the current time.
They reach the small hole and witness a disgusting scene: Old Bian is tearing at the Professor's corpse.
Old Bian notices them and quickly disappears into the small hole.
The narrator examines the Professor's corpse and finds a metallic reflection in a wound.
The narrator calls for Shao Ye to look.
The narrator looks up and finds he is alone in the tomb.
The narrator is terrified of being alone in the ancient tomb with the dead.
The narrator sees a shadow by the coffin river.
Shao Ye's voice calls out, telling the narrator not to come closer.
The narrator finds Shao Ye and Ya Tou by the coffin river.
Ya Tou is squatting, indicating she needs to relieve herself again.
The narrator explains that Shao Ye and Ya Tou had moved to a more private spot.
The narrator tells Shao Ye about the strange metallic reflection on the Professor's corpse.
Shao Ye mentions the strange hole and long chain in the coffin river.
The narrator asks Ya Tou if she is finished.
There is silence from Ya Tou's location.
The narrator becomes concerned when he receives no response.
A loud noise is heard from above.
The narrator fears Ya Tou has also encountered trouble.
Chapter 2: Fake Person White Fox.
Shao Ye repeatedly fails to hook the beam with the rope.
The narrator succeeds in hooking the beam and starts climbing.
The narrator looks back and is shocked, losing his grip and falling.
Shao Ye catches the narrator.
The narrator exclaims about the Professor's body.
The Professor's corpse, which was by the small hole, has disappeared.
The small hole has closed, making the tomb appear seamless.
The narrator explains the situation to Shao Ye.
Shao Ye prioritizes finding Ya Tou.
Shao Ye climbs up the rope, followed by the narrator.
They look down and are stunned.
Ya Tou is lying on the white jade coffin.
They are shocked by how Ya Tou got onto the coffin and ended up there.
Shao Ye signals to go down, and the narrator follows.
They circle the coffin but are afraid to touch Ya Tou.
The narrator checks Ya Tou's pulse and finds it cold.
The narrator fears Ya Tou is dead.
Ya Tou makes a gasping sound from her throat.
The narrator attempts CPR on Ya Tou.
Shao Ye takes over CPR.
The narrator observes the empty armor shell, noting that it previously attracted black corpses but now causes no reaction.
A crisp sound is heard.
Shao Ye is looking at Ya Tou with a swollen face.
Ya Tou has sat up on the coffin.
The narrator asks Ya Tou if she is alright.
Ya Tou is confused about how she got there.
The narrator explains the events.
Ya Tou recalls having a stomach ache and needing to relieve herself.
After relieving herself, Ya Tou felt dizzy and ended up on the coffin.
The narrator believes the place is extremely sinister and they need to find Liu Qu's epitaph to lift the curse.
They agree to focus on survival.
Shao Ye suggests investigating the armor shell for clues.
The narrator is surprised that Ya Tou is unharmed after her strange experience.
The narrator is relieved that Ya Tou is alive.
Shao Ye jumps off the coffin to examine the armor.
Ya Tou looks towards a specific point with a strange expression.
The narrator follows Ya Tou's gaze and sees a blurry black shadow in a small palace structure within the tomb.
Shao Ye calls for the narrator to look at something.

concepts.name: Yellow River Ghost Coffin 2
concepts.context: Title of the document.

concepts.name: Corpse Transformation Nine Dragon Pit
concepts.context: Subtitle of the document.

concepts.name: Nen Pai San Shu
concepts.context: Author or related entity of the book.

concepts.name: TXT Novel Paradise
concepts.context: Website mentioned for reading novels.

concepts.name: Narrator
concepts.context: The first-person protagonist of the story, also referred to as 'I' or 'Old Xu'.

concepts.name: Shao Ye
concepts.context: A character accompanying the narrator, often referred to as 'Young Master'.

concepts.name: Ya Tou
concepts.context: A female character, an archaeologist, accompanying the narrator and Shao Ye.

concepts.name: Tomb
concepts.context: The primary setting of the story.

concepts.name: Jade platform
concepts.context: A significant object within the tomb.

concepts.name: Armor
concepts.context: An empty suit of armor found in the tomb.

concepts.name: Footsteps
concepts.context: A recurring sound that causes fear and signals danger.

concepts.name: Terror
concepts.context: The emotional state experienced by the characters due to the strange events.

concepts.name: Iron chains
concepts.context: Associated with the mysterious approaching figures.

concepts.name: Door
concepts.context: An unexpected opening within the tomb.

concepts.name: Shadowy figures
concepts.context: The mysterious entities that appear in the tomb.

concepts.name: Black corpses
concepts.context: The primary antagonists encountered in Chapter 1, described as reanimated corpses.

concepts.name: Stone wall cracks
concepts.context: Where similar black corpses were previously seen.

concepts.name: Crossbow
concepts.context: A weapon used by Shao Ye.

concepts.name: Bamboo arrow
concepts.context: A projectile weapon used by the characters.

concepts.name: Decaying corpses
concepts.context: The foul smell emanating from the antagonists.

concepts.name: Stomach ache
concepts.context: A physical ailment experienced by Ya Tou.

concepts.name: Feminine hygiene pad
concepts.context: An unexpected item used to defeat the black corpses.

concepts.name: Corpse poison
concepts.context: A potential danger from the decaying corpses or their remains.

concepts.name: Beams
concepts.context: A structural element of the tomb where the characters hide.

concepts.name: Echo walls
concepts.context: A hypothetical architectural feature that might be causing sounds.

concepts.name: Dog hole
concepts.context: A small opening in the tomb's wall.

concepts.name: Old Bian
concepts.context: A deceased individual who reappears in the tomb.

concepts.name: Professor
concepts.context: Another deceased individual who reappears in the tomb.

concepts.name: Coffin river
concepts.context: A river-like feature within the tomb containing hazardous elements.

concepts.name: Tentacles
concepts.context: Creatures found within the coffin river.

concepts.name: Liu Qu
concepts.context: An individual associated with the tomb and its treasures.

concepts.name: White jade coffin
concepts.context: A prominent object in the tomb, Ya Tou is found lying on it.

concepts.name: CPR
concepts.context: A resuscitation technique performed on Ya Tou.

concepts.name: Palace structure
concepts.context: A smaller architectural element within the tomb.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured into two main chapters. Chapter 1 focuses on the initial encounter with reanimated corpses and the discovery of a hidden mechanism. Chapter 2 details the disappearance and reappearance of characters and their corpses, leading to further mysterious events within the tomb.
